parameter.help: True: if the regular expression is found, the first array element contains the length and position, respectively, of the first match. If the regular expression contains parentheses that group subexpressions, each subsequent array element contains the length and position, respectively, of the first occurrence of each group. If the regular expression is not found, the arrays each contain one element with the value 0. False: the function returns the position in the string where the match begins. Default.

function.name: removechars
function.help: Removes characters from a string.

function.name: repeatstring
function.help: Creates a string that contains a specified number of repetitions of the specified string.

function.name: replace
function.help: Replaces occurrences of substring1 in a string with substring2, in a specified scope. The search is case-sensitive.

parameter.name: scope
parameter.help: * one: replace the first occurrence (default) * all: replace all occurrences

function.name: replacelist

function.name: replacenocase
function.help: Replaces occurrences of substring1 with substring2, in the specified scope. The search is case-insensitive.

parameter.name: String
parameter.help: A string (or variable that contains one) within which to replace substring

parameter.name: scope
parameter.help: * one: Replace the first occurrence (default) * all: Replace all occurrences

function.name: rereplace

parameter.help: A string or a variable that contains one

parameter.name: substring
parameter.help: A string or a variable that contains one. Replaces reg_expression

parameter.name: scope
parameter.help: * one: Replace the first occurrence of the regular expression. Default. * all: Replace all occurrences of the regular expression.

function.name: rereplacenocase
function.help: Uses a regular expression to search a string for a string pattern and replace it with another. The search is case-insensitive.

parameter.name: String
parameter.help: A string or a variable that contains one

parameter.name: reg_expression
parameter.help: Regular expression to replace.

parameter.name: substring
parameter.help: A string or a variable that contains one. Replaces reg_expression

parameter.name: scope
parameter.help: * one: Replace the first occurrence of the regular expression. Default. * all: Replace all occurrences of the regular expression.

function.name: reverse
function.help: Reverses the order of items, such as the characters in a string, the digits in a number, or the elements in an array.

parameter.name: String
parameter.help: A string or a variable that contains one

function.name: right
function.help: Gets a specified number of characters from a string, beginning at the right.

parameter.name: count
parameter.help: A positive integer or a variable that contains one. Number of characters to return.

function.name: rjustify
function.help: Right justifies characters of a string.

function.name: round
function.help: Rounds a number to the closest integer.

function.name: rtrim

parameter.name: String
parameter.help: A string or a variable that contains one

parameter.name: date

parameter.name: charset
parameter.help: The character encoding in which text in the scope variables is encoded.

function.name: setlocale
function.help: Sets the country/language locale for CFML processing and the page returned to the client. The locale value determines the default format of date, time, number, and currency values, according to language and regional conventions.

parameter.name: new_locale
parameter.help: The name of a locale; for example, "English (US)"

function.name: setprofilestring

parameter.name: value
parameter.help: Value to which to set the entry

parameter.name: name
parameter.help: Variable name

parameter.name: value
parameter.help: A string, the name of a string, or a number

function.name: sgn
function.help: Determines the sign of a number.

function.name: sin
function.help: Calculates the sine of an angle that is entered in radians.

parameter.name: set
parameter.help: A string or a variable that contains a set of characters. Must contain one or more characters

parameter.help: A string or a variable that contains one

parameter.name: overwriteFlag

parameter.name: structure
parameter.help: Structure to clear

parameter.name: structure

function.help: Searches recursively through a substructure of nested arrays, structures, and other elements, for structures whose values match the search key in the value parameter.

parameter.help: CFML object (structure or array) from which to start search. This attribute requires an object, not a name of an object.

parameter.name: value
parameter.help: String or a variable that contains one for which to search.

parameter.name: scope
parameter.help: * one: returns one matching key. Default. * all: returns all matching keys

function.name: structfindvalue
function.help: Searches recursively through a substructure of nested arrays, structures, and other elements for structures with values that match the search key in the value parameter.

parameter.name: top
parameter.help: CFML object (a structure or an array) from which to start search. This attribute requires an object, not a name of an object.

parameter.name: value
parameter.help: String or a variable that contains one for which to search. The type must be a simple object. Arrays and structures are not supported.

parameter.name: scop
parameter.help: one: function returns one matching key (default) all: function returns all matching keys

parameter.name: value
parameter.help: Value to add.

parameter.name: allowoverwrite

parameter.name: structure

parameter.name: caseSensitiveKeys
parameter.help: Indicates whether or not the structure should allow case sensitive key names. Defaults to false.

parameter.help: * numeric * text: case sensitive Default. * textnocase

parameter.name: pathtosubelement
parameter.help: String or a variable that contains one

function.help: Formats a time value using US English time formatting conventions. If no mask is specified, returns a time value using the hh:mm tt format. For international time formatting, see LSTimeFormat. [mask] h,hh,H,HH: Hours; m,mm: Minutes; s,ss: Seconds; l: Milliseconds; t: A or P; tt: AM or PM "short" = h:mm tt; "medium" = h:mm:ss tt

parameter.name: time

parameter.name: mask
parameter.help: Masking characters that determine the format

parameter.name: encoding

parameter.name: String
parameter.help: A string or a variable that contains one

parameter.name: String
parameter.help: A string or a variable that contains one

parameter.name: String
parameter.help: A string or a variable that contains one

parameter.name: charset
parameter.help: The character encoding in which the string is encoded.

parameter.name: String

Response character character set (character encoding) specified by the response Content-Type header.

If the connection to the HTTP server fails, contains details about the failure. For instance: "Unknown host: my.co.com"; otherwise, the empty string. Macromedia recommends that you check this variable for an error condition before checking other variables.
Response body; for example: the contents of a html page retrieved by a GET operation. Empty if you save the response in a file.
Raw response header containing all header information in a single string. Contains the same information as the #cfhttp.responseHeader# variable.
MIME type specified by the response Content-Type header, Example: text/html

The response headers formatted into a structure. Each element key is the header name, such as Content-Type or Status_Code. If there is more than one instance of a header type, the type values are put in an array. One common technique is to dynamically access the cfhttp.responseHeader structure as a dynamic array, example: #cfhttp.resonseHeader[fieldVariable]#
The HTTP status_code header value followed by the HTTP Explanation header value. Example: 200 OK

Boolean; True if the response body content type is text. ColdFusion recognizes the response body as text if: The header does not specify a content type, or it starts with "text" or "message" or the full content type="application/octet-stream".
All HTTP headers that were not already parsed into one of the listed variables. These variables are of the form HTTP_header field name with each variable separated by a semi-colon

(IIS) Retrieves all headers in raw form. The difference between CGI.ALL_RAW and CGI.ALL_HTTP is that CGI.ALL_HTTP places an HTTP_ prefix before the header name and the header name is always capitalized. In ALL_RAW the header name and values appear as they are sent by the client.

(IIS) Returns the name of the application pool that is running in the IIS worker process that is handling the request. There is also an CGI.APP_POOL_ID environment variable that is available to applications that are running in the IIS worker process. (Note: IIS 5.1 and earlier: This server variable is not available.)
(IIS) Retrieves the metabase path of the application.
(IIS) Retrieves the physical path corresponding to the metabase path in CGI.APPL_MD_PATH.
(IIS) The value entered in the client's authentication dialog. This variable is available only if Basic authentication is used.
If the server supports user authentication, and the script is protected, this is the protocol-specific authentication method used to validate the user.

(IIS) The name of the user as it is derived from the authorization header sent by the client, before the user name is mapped to a Windows account. This variable is no different from CGI.REMOTE_USER. If you have an authentication filter installed on your Web server that maps incoming users to accounts, use CGI.LOGON_USER to view the mapped user name.
(IIS) Returns the full URL Example: http://www.macromedia.com:80/index.cfm?query=string (Note: IIS 5.1 and earlier: This server variable is not available.)
(IIS) Unique ID for the client certificate, returned as a string. This can be used as a signature for the whole client certificate.

(IIS) bit0 is set to 1 if the client certificate is present. bit1 is set to 1 if the certification authority of the client certificate is invalid (that is, it is not in the list of recognized certification authorities on the server). If bit 1 of CGI.CERT_FLAGS is set to 1, indicating that the certificate is invalid, IIS version 4.0 and later will reject the certificate. (Note: Earlier versions of IIS will not reject the certificate.)
Issuer field of the client certificate (O=MS, OU=IAS, CN=user name, C=USA).
(IIS) Number of bits in the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) connection key size. Example: 128
(IIS) Number of bits in server certificate private key. Example: 1024
(IIS) Serial number field of the client certificate.
(IIS) Issuer field of the server certificate.
(IIS) Subject field of the server certificate.
Subject field of the client certificate.
Show the entire file path to the coldfusion template, similar to CGI.PATH_TRANSLATED. Example: c:\inetpub\wwwroot\somesite\somepage.cfm
The length of the content as given by the client.
For queries that have attached information, such as HTTP POST and PUT, this is the content type of the data.
(Apache SSI) The current date and time in Greenwich Mean Time (now Unviversal Co-ordinated Time (UCT) in the default or #config defined format). Thursday, 03-May-2001 21:18:54 GMT
(Apache SSI) The current date and time in the local (server) timezone (in the default or #config defined format), Example: Thursday, 03-May-2001 17:18:54 EDT

(Zeus SSI) This will be set to the CGI.QUERY_STRING of the master document. The value of CGI.QUERY_STRING for an SSI sub-request will contain the query string in the sub-request URL, if present, else the master document's CGI.QUERY_STRING.
(Apache SSI) The file name (excludes directories) of the document requested by the user. Example: ssi.htm
(Apache SSI/Zeus SSI) This will be set to the CGI.PATH_INFO of the master document.
(Apache SSI) The root directory of this site defined by the 'DocumentRoot' directive in the General Section or a <virtualhost> section. Example: /var/www/zytrax
(Apache SSI/Zeus SSI) The URL path of the document requested by the user. Example: /tech/web/ssi.htm
The revision of the CGI specification to which this server complies. Format: CGI/revision.
List of Content-types the browser can accept (defined by the HTTP Accept header).
(IIS) Returns a list of accepted encoding types. Example: gzip, deflate
(IIS) Returns a string describing the language to use for displaying content.
(IIS) Returns a string describing the connection type. Example: Keep-Alive
(IIS) Returns the cookie string that was included with the request.
(IIS) Returns the name of the Web server. This may or may not be the same as CGI.SERVER_NAME depending on type of name resolution you are using on your Web server (IP address, host header).
(IIS) The method used to make the request (Note: same as CGI.REQUEST_METHOD).
The referring document. The document that linked to or submitted form data.
(IIS) Returns the raw, encoded URL. Example: /vdir/default.asp?querystring
The browser the client is currently using to send the request. Format: software/version library/version.
(IIS) The name and version of the request protocol (the raw form of CGI.SERVER_PROTOCOL).
(IIS/Zeus) Returns ON if the request came in through a secure channel; or it returns OFF, if the request is for an insecure channel. Example: SSL
(IIS/Zeus) Number of bits in the SSL connection key size. Example: 128
(IIS/Zeus) Number of bits in the server certificate private key. Example: 1024
(IIS) Issuer field of the server certificate.
(IIS) Subject field of the server certificate.
(Zeus SSI) The value of the session id used by the SSL session. This value is unique for each distinct SSL session

(IIS) The ID for the IIS instance in textual format. If the instance ID is 1, it appears as a string. You can use this variable to retrieve the ID of the Web server instance (in the metabase) to which the request belongs.
(IIS) The metabase path for the instance of IIS that responds to the request.

(Apache SSI) The last modification date of the document (file) requested by the user (in the default or #config defined format). This variable related to the file currently being accessed i.e. if you put this is an included 'footer' file is is the modification date of the footer NOT the base document (you need to use a simple 'wheeze' to pass a USER variable which contains the calling documents modification date (see here). Example: Thursday, 03-May-2001 17:18:45 EDT

(IIS) Returns the server address on which the request came in. This is important on computers where there can be multiple IP addresses bound to the computer, and you want to find out which address the request used.

(IIS) The Windows account that the user is impersonating while connected to your Web server. Use CGI.REMOTE_USER, CGI.UNMAPPED_REMOTE_USER, or CGI.AUTH_USER to view the raw user name that is contained in the request header. The only time CGI.LOGON_USER holds a different value than these other variables is if you have an authentication filter installed.
(Apache) The PATH(s) available to the server for this web site Example: /sbin:/usr/sbin:/bin:/usr/bin:/usr/X11R6/bin

The extra path information, as given by the client. In other words, scripts can be accessed by their virtual pathname, followed by extra information at the end of this path. The extra information is sent as CGI.PATH_INFO.
The server provides a translated version of CGI.PATH_INFO, which takes the path and does any virtual-to-physical mapping to it.
The query information that follows the ? in the URL that referenced this script.
The IP address of the remote host making the request.
The hostname making the request. If the server does not have this information, it sets CGI.REMOTE_ADDR and leaves this unset.
If the HTTP server supports RFC 931 identification, then this variable is set to the remote user name retrieved from the server. Usage of this variable should be limited to logging only.
(IIS) The client port number of the TCP connection.
If the server supports user authentication, and the script is protected, this is the username they have authenticated as. (Also available as CGI.AUTH_USER.)
The entity body (if any) sent with an HTTP request or response is in a format and encoding defined by the Entity-Header fields. See the HTTP protocol specification for details.
The method with which the request was made. For HTTP, this "GET", "HEAD", "POST", etc.
(Apache) The URI for this request (relative to CGI.DOCUMENT_ROOT) Example: /tech/web/ssi.htm
(Apache) The path to the script being executed (relative to CGI.DOCUMENT_ROOT) Example: /tech/web/ssi.htm
A virtual path to the script being executed, used for self-referencing URLs.
(IIS) The canonical physical path to the script listed in CGI.SCRIPT_NAME Example: \\?\c:\inetpub\wwwroot\vdir\default.asp (Note: IIS 5.1 and earlier: This server variable is not available.)
(Apache) The administrators e-mail address for this CGI.SERVER_NAME. Example: webmaster@zytrax.com
The servers hostname, DNS alias, or IP address as it appears in self-referencing URLs.
The port number to which the request was sent.
(IIS) A string that contains either 0 or 1. If the request is being handled on the secure port, then this is 1. Otherwise, it is 0.
The name and revision of the information protocol this request came in with. Format: protocol/revision.
(Apache) The HTML string that may be embedded in the page to identify this host. Example: <address>Apache/1.3.14 Server at www.zytrax.com Port 80</address>
The name and version of the information server software answering the request (and running the gateway). Format: name/version.

(IIS) Returns a 1 if the server-side include directive, #exec, is disabled. Otherwise, CGI.SSI_EXE_DISABLED returns a 0. To enable or disable #exec, use the SSIExecDisablemetabase property. (Note: IIS 5.1 and earlier: This server variable is not available.)
(IIS) Returns the raw, unencoded URL Example: /vdir/default.asp?querystring (Note: IIS 4.0 and earlier: This server variable is not available)

(IIS) The name of the user as it is derived from the authorization header sent by the client, before the user name is mapped to a Windows account (same as CGI.REMOTE_USER). If you have an authentication filter installed on your Web server that maps incoming users to accounts, use CGI.LOGON_USER to view the mapped user name.
(IIS) Gives the base portion of the URL, without any querystring or extra path information. For the raw URL, use CGI.HTTP_URL or CGI.UNENCODED_URL. Example: "/vdir/default.asp".
(IIS) Use CGI.PATH_INFO instead. (Note: This server variable is only available on IIS 5.0.)
(Apache SSI) The user name of the web site in which this web site runs. Example: zytrax
The exception's type, possible values: Application, Database, Template, Security, Object, MissingInclude, Expression, Lock, SearchEngine or a Custom Type.
A detailed message from the CFML compiler. This message, which can contain HTML formatting, can help to determine which tag threw the exception.

The cfthrow tag can supply a value for this code through the errorCode attribute. For Type="Database", CFCATCH.ErrorCode has the same value as CFCATCH.SQLState. Otherwise, the value of CFCATCH.ErrorCode is the empty string.
Custom error message information. This is returned only to CFCATCH tags for which the type attribute is "Application" or a custom type. Otherwise, the value of CFCATCH.ExtendedInfo is empty.
The exception's default diagnostic message, if one was provided. If no diagnostic message is available, this is empty.
Array of tag information structures.
Obsolete (retained for backwards compatibility). Always 0.
The tag in which the exception occurred. Exceptions in CFScript are indicated by two question marks (??). All custom tags, including those called directly, are identified as cfmodule.
The line on the page in which the tag is located.
The raw Java stack trace for the error.
The pathname of the application page that contains the tag.
The type of page; it is always a ColdFusion page.
An internal expression error number. Available for expression exceptions.
The name of the affected lock. This is set to "anonymous" if the lock name is unknown. Available for locking exceptions.
The operation that failed. This is set to "unknown" if the failed operation is unknown. Available for locking exceptions.
The name of the missing file. Available for missingInclude exceptions.

The native error code associated with this exception. Database drivers typically provide error codes to assist in the diagnosis of failing database operations. The values assumed by CFCATCH.NativeErrorCode are driver-dependent. If no error code is provided, the value of CFCATCH.nativeErrorCode is -1. The value is 0 for queries of queries. Available for database exceptions.

The SQLState code associated with this exception. Database drivers typically provide error codes to assist in the diagnosis of failing database operations. SQLState codes are more consistent across database systems than native error codes. If the driver does not provide an SQLState value, the value of CFCATCH.SQLState is -1. Available for database exceptions.
The SQL statement sent to the data source. Available for database exceptions.
The error message as reported by the database driver. Available for database exceptions.
If the query uses the cfqueryparam tag, query parameter name-value pairs. Available for database exceptions.
Unordered list of validation errors that occurred. This includes any text that you specify in the value attribute or a hidden tag used to validate form input. Available for Validation type errors.
Text for the header of the default validation message. Available for Validation type errors.
Text for the footer of the default validation message. Available for Validation type errors.
Browser that was running when the error occurred. Available for Exception and Request type errors.
Date and time when the error occurred. Available for Exception and Request type errors.
Detailed error diagnostics. Available for Exception and Request type errors.
Any content that ColdFusion generated in response to the request prior to the error. Available for Exception and Request type errors.

Page containing the HTML link to the page on which the error occurred. This value is an empty string if the user specified the page directly in the browser. (string). Available for Exception and Request type errors
E-mail address of the administrator who should be notified. This value is set in the mailTo attribute of the cferror tag. Available for Exception and Request type errors.
URL query string of the client's request, if any. Available for Exception and Request type errors.
IP address of the remote client. Available for Exception and Request type errors.
Page being executed when the error occurred. Available for Exception and Request type errors.
Error message associated with the exception. Available for Exception type errors.
Java servlet exception reported by the JVM as the cause of the "root cause" of the exception. Available for Exception type errors.
Exception type, possible values: Application, Database, Template, Security, Object, MissingInclude, Expression, Lock, SearchEngine or a Custom Type.
Array of structures containing information for each tag in the tag stack The tag stack consists of each tag that is currently open. Available for Exception type errors.
Obsolete (retained for backwards compatibility). Always 0.
The tag in which the exception occurred. Exceptions in CFScript are indicated by two question marks (??). All custom tags, including those called directly, are identified as cfmodule.
The line on the page in which the tag is located. (int)
The raw Java stack trace for the error.
The pathname of the application page that contains the tag.
The type of page; it is always a ColdFusion page.
Unordered list of validation errors that occurred. This includes any text that you specify in the value attribute or a hidden tag used to validate form input. Available for Validation type errors.
Text for the header of the default validation message. Available for Validation type errors.
Text for the footer of the default validation message. Available for Validation type errors.
Browser that was running when the error occurred. Available for Exception and Request type errors.
Date and time when the error occurred. Available for Exception and Request type errors.
Detailed error diagnostics. Available for Exception and Request type errors.
Any content that ColdFusion generated in response to the request prior to the error. Available for Exception and Request type errors.

Page containing the HTML link to the page on which the error occurred. This value is an empty string if the user specified the page directly in the browser. (string). Available for Exception and Request type errors
E-mail address of the administrator who should be notified. This value is set in the mailTo attribute of the ERROR tag. Available for Exception and Request type errors.
URL query string of the client's request, if any. Available for Exception and Request type errors.
IP address of the remote client. Available for Exception and Request type errors.
Page being executed when the error occurred. Available for Exception and Request type errors.
Error message associated with the exception. Available for Exception type errors.
Java servlet exception reported by the JVM as the cause of the "root cause" of the exception. Available for Exception type errors.
Exception type, possible values: Application, Database, Template, Security, Object, MissingInclude, Expression, Lock, SearchEngine or a Custom Type.
Array of structures containing information for each tag in the tag stack The tag stack consists of each tag that is currently open. Available for Exception type errors.
Obsolete (retained for backwards compatibility). Always 0.
The tag in which the exception occurred. Exceptions in CFScript are indicated by two question marks (??). All custom tags, including those called directly, are identified as cfmodule.
